summary: Ok so, my fellow Game of Thrones fans, I’ve been through some of the tags and have seen that ya’ll keep harping about Sansa v...
body: Ok so, my fellow Game of Thrones fans, I’ve been through some of the tags and have seen that ya’ll keep harping about Sansa v Daenerys and who’s copying whose hair, but you do realize that Sansa copying Dany or Dany copying Sansa is not possible because THEY HAVE NOT CANONICALLY MET YET AND HAVE NO CLUE WHAT THE OTHER LOOKS LIKE MUCH LESS HOW THEY DO THEIR HAIR RIGHT? This stupid discourse is fucking cancelled. I ain’t in this shit for the hair discourse. I’m here for fucking dragons, bitchin fight scenes, Jaime’s character development, and the Stark dream team.

summary: Sansa doesn’t owe Tyrion Anything
title: Sansa doesn’t owe Tyrion Anything
body:
Why do so many people in the fandom think Sansa owes Tyrion love? I find it incredibly gross how many people route for Sanrion like it would be a healthy relationship for either of them. I understand that the show didn’t quite accuratly depict Tyrion as a bad person he is but he was by no means a saint or owed anything. Everyone who ships them for some reason thinks that Sansa owes him her love and body because they deluded them selves into believing it is owed to him due to his few incidents of kindness or because of his treatment by his family. They casually ignore all of the glaringly obvious reasons why Sansa especially owes him anything. And they for some reason think that Sansa not loving him is a flaw in her character, saying ablism is why she won’t sleep with him.

Tyrion is not a good person GRRM himself called him a villain. Tyrion does many awful things especially to Sansa and her family. He raped a slave in Essos, He is given a young woman known only as the “sunset girl,” and her back is covered from the scars of previous whippings. You know he know what he is doing is wrong because Tyrion mentally noting that “she did not prove the liveliest of partners” and that she had eyes that “looked dead.” Knowing she’s punished for disobeying her masters, Tyrion thinks he has just had sex with a dead woman. He’s filled with shame and thinks “this was a mistake”… which doesn’t keep him from raping her again, after which she runs away. Unlike in the tv show it is quite obvious that Shea doesn’t love him to everyone even Tyrion doesn’t believe she actually loves him. Then he kills her because she “betrayed” him in the show she reaches for a knife this doesn’t happen in the book. What do you think would happen to Shea if she refused Cersei or Tywin? The fact that at is trail he had an outburst and says he wished to poison them all. 

That’s without mentioning all his crimes against Sansa. He helps keep Sansa imprisioned in kings landing while yes he has a reason for doing this it still is not a good thing. For some bizarre reason everyone like pretending that he is just as much of a prisoner as Sansa which is laughable. He actively plots against her family while yes he didn’t plot the red wedding the death of Sansa’s family was one of the things he wanted. Then you get to there wedding where he married a 12 year old girl against her will. He embarrassed her by getting drunk. Then joke about raping her. He says,  “Come, wife, time to smash your portcullis. I want to play come-into-the-castle.”. He knows that anything that happens between them is not consensual but still he jokes about it to her like it wouldn’t scare her. Then he molested his 12 YEAR OLD, CHILD BRIDE and stops seconds from actually raping her and the awful thing is that the reason he stops is more to do with his feelings and the fact that unlike other women she can’t fake interest in him. Despite all this for some reason Sansa hopes for his safety while he is angry at her for not returning his pedophlic lust for her. 

Then you get into the fact that for some reason people thinks it Sansa’s duty to love him or sleep with him saying it is just his looks that stop her but there are way more important reason for her not to.  Like him being a Lannister and her feeling it would be a betrayal to her family. If she has child it would inherit winterfell and the north giving both on a platter to the Lannister. Then there is a more obvious one the fact tat she is a 12 year old girl with a poor sexual education and Cersei and Joffery always telling her how painful and violent it would be scaring her of sex in general and her past experiences with men. The men at the bread riot, attempting to rape her and Pycelle and Sandor molesting her cause her allot of distress around her sexuality. Why would anyone in there right mind blame her? 

Inclusion She doesn’t owe Tyrion Shit and he doesn’t deserve her love anyway.

summary: Passion
title: Passion
body:
Link to part 1: http://zalrb.tumblr.com/post/164720175550/trust-jonsa-one-shot

Link to part 2: http://zalrb.tumblr.com/post/181817838525/an-entirely-different-way-pt-2

I was inspired to keep on going. Hope you guys like it! Once again, I’m not heavy into GoT, like I’m not too good with Houses and with customs etc. etc. so bear with me.

Sansa could hear it as she strode through the corridors. Giggling. Whispering. It was coming from an empty chamber. Choruses of “shh!” “shh!” and more guffawing. She was on her way to a council with Jon and the others but her curiosity got the best of her and she stopped outside of the room in question, its door half-closed, and saw a few servants huddled together.

           “I mean, it makes sense doesn’t it? Nothing makes a man lose his senses like a good roll in the hay.”

           The laughing stopped the minute Sansa made her presence known and the servants disassembled from a circle and formed a line, bowing their heads to her.

           “Lady Stark,” they intoned.

           She closed the door fully and walked closer to where they stood. “What is it that you are all talking about?”

           No one said anything. She sighed.

           “I know that you’re all gossiping in here, just tell me what it is.”

Two servants exchanged nervous glances. “Forgive us, Lady Stark—”

“You’re not in any trouble,” she said with a slight smile. “I’m just … curious. Indulge me.”

A woman started to speak. “Lady Stark, we … … we heard a rumour—”

“Yes,” said Sansa, nodding. “That much has been made clear.” She regarded them. “Out with it.”

There was another pause before the woman continued speaking. “One of the servants, I’m not sure who exactly, heard some of the boat crew talking,” she said. “And…”

Sansa stared at her. Her heart began to race as dread creeped up on her and started squeezing her chest: maybe she didn’t want to hear the answer. Maybe it was a rumour that would shatter something inside of her. It was the only explanation for the sense of impending doom that was disrupting her body.

“His Grace, Lord Snow, he and the Targaryen woman … they … they had relations on the boat…”

“That is the gossip anyway, my Lady,” said a man.

Nothing could have prepared Sansa for those words; they struck her like a slap and she felt winded with the impact. More than that she felt betrayed in a way she hadn’t expected. There was an intimacy to her sense of betrayal, an intimacy that shook her because it made her feel as if Jon had been unfaithful rather than traitorous, adulterous even and that only spawned a familiar confusion in Sansa, the one that had plagued her after every interaction she’d had with Jon since he came back.

It was as if her insides were being ripped apart with the whirlwind of conflicting emotions and all she could do to hold herself together was remove herself from them, block herself from the surprising pain and all of its implications, turn herself into steel, into that statuesque demeanour she found herself inhabiting more and more.

“Thank you, that will be all,” she said. Her jaw tight. “You can get back to your duties.”

“My Lady.”

 

Jon sat opposite Daenerys at a long wooden table covered with maps and documents. He was staring down at nothing in particular, stewing in a broody silence that infected the entire room. Daenerys had seen moments of this beforehand but nothing quite so long-lasting.

“It is unlike Sansa to be late,” he said.

Daenerys regarded him. “You’re worried about her?”

“I’m …” He gesticulated. “Regretful that we haven’t been getting along lately.”

“Because of me,” said Daenerys.

“No, because she doesn’t trust me. Because she’s stubborn. Because she doesn’t have faith in my loyalty to—” He cut himself off and shook his head.

Daenerys saw the heartbreak in Jon’s eyes as he said those words, heard the way his voice quickened with frustration and with a need, even then, to make his sister understand his choices — he was always with Sansa, he carried her with him, and all of their impassioned discussions.

“Well anyone with eyes could see how much you love …” she licked her lips. “The North,” she finished diplomatically. “Perhaps she just needed some time to gain perspective.”

“Well then she would’ve done it after the meeting not before,” said Jon gruffly.

The door opened and he started but when he saw Davos walk in the room, he sat back in his chair, crestfallen.

“Your Grace,” he said swiftly. He stopped in the middle of the room and spoke just as quickly.

“You need to talk to your crew. They’re undisciplined and they have big mouths.”

Daenerys stood up. “I beg your pardon?”

Jon raised his hands in a calming manner, looking from Daenerys to Davos and then spoke.

“What is it?”

“There seems to be a rumour going around,” said Davos.

Daenerys looked at him, her head cocked upward and Jon narrowed his eyes at Davos’ awkward expression.

“A rumour that you two had …”

Jon didn’t need Davos to finish the sentence. Everything inside of him shifted. He could hear Daenerys scoff at the accusations, at Davos discussing methods to suppress the gossip but their words were distant echoes in his ears. He suddenly felt sick with worry, with anxiety.

“Did Sansa hear?” he whispered.

They continued to talk.

He cleared his throat. “Did Sansa hear?” he said more loudly.

“Uh…” Davos shrugged. “I’m not sure if any of your siblings heard, Your Grace, right now it seems to be confined to the common folk, I —”

“I need to find her,” said Jon. He looked to Daenerys. “Excuse me.”

 

Jon walked into Sansa’s room without knocking, closing the door behind him. She was sitting at her desk, looking over documents. Although he was restless, he didn’t dare speak but she did nothing to acknowledge his presence in her chambers. He wanted to pace but he also wanted to stay still, he wanted to shout at her to look at him but he also wanted to give her the first word. He was unusually ambivalent and unusually frazzled and he couldn’t understand the guilt that was the source of his agitation.

Finally, she spoke.

“Do you love her?” she asked quietly, her eyes still on the document in front her.

“Sansa—-”

“Do. You. Love. Her.”

Jon sighed and hung his head then took a couple of steps closer to her desk. Finally she looked at him. Her eyes blazing with that wintry fire he so admired, that wintry fire that contradicted the coolness of her speech. She shrugged her shoulders.

“I don’t know if it would make this mean something or feel like it means something if you were in love with her.”

“Sansa, stop it.”

“Well surely,” she leaned back in her chair and shook her head, “if you are going to give away our autonomy, our freedom, it should be for love, should it not?”

“Sansa.”

She stood up and slammed her hands on the desk. “You tried to make me feel like a fool for questioning your motivations for this decision.”

“Well you were being a bit foolish,” Jon snapped back. “You’re being foolish right now!”

“Am I?” she yelled. Her pretence of aloofness cracking. “Because the last time someone from our family made a decision based on a woman, he ended up dead! My mother ended up dead! Northerners ended up dead! I told you you had to be smarter than Father, that you had to be smarter than Robb! And you’re making the same mistakes—”

Jon slammed his hands on the desk now too, his face inches away from Sansa’s. “I am not making the same mistakes!” he yelled. “I would never do anything to put the North at risk, to put Arya and Bran at risk, to put you at risk, Sansa! How many times do we have to have the same argument?”

“Until you convince me!” The shrillness of her own yelling surprised Sansa, it was a mark of how personal she was taking the entire situation and she tried to regain some emotional distance.

“Do you know how weak this makes us look? The King in the North now a puppet because he doesn’t think with his head!”

“Sansa, that’s enough!” He took a beat. “I would never—!”

“Oh, you’re too blinded that you don’t even see it!”

Swiftly, Sansa wrenched her eyes from Jon’s gaze and turned her back to him, rubbing her forehead with her right hand. She was feverish, her skin was hot to the touch.

“Too blinded to see what?” said Jon.

He waited for a response and when he didn’t get one, something in him compelled him to shout. “What am I too blinded to see?”

Sansa whirled around. “That you have chosen her!” she yelled. “Over — over—” Me, she screamed internally. You chose an outsider over me! And I hate it and I don’t know why I hate it this much!

Jon walked around the desk to her, he touched her shoulder but she couldn’t bear the thought of him holding her with the same hands he held her and she stepped out of his reach. While Jon itched to try again, he stayed where he was, giving her the space that she demanded, as he had and would continue to ensure that never again would she be touched unless she’d wanted to be.

She stared at him, breathing heavily and he shook his head, doing his best to calm the rage within him. He took a step toward her and stopped, maintaining a distance. “I—” he pressed his lips together. “I never knew you thought so little of me.”

She rolled her eyes. “That isn’t what I’m saying.”

“Isn’t it?” he countered. “If you so … passionately believe that I would put everything and everyone at risk for something as crude as sex or as selfish as love then I —”

“So you do love her,” she said severely, her eyes flashing.

He looked at her wearily. “Look, I loved a woman once,” he said. “A Wildling woman, her name was Ygritte and even my love for her couldn’t come before my duty to the Night’s Watch, what makes you think anything can come before my duty to —” You. “My people?”

“You love her,” she repeated.

Jon gritted his teeth, opening and closing his fists. “Why do you keep saying that?”

“Why don’t you deny it?” she retorted.

He looked at her, his mouth agape, as something — a new emotion — tickled his chest. Something that felt a bit like hope or a bit like delight.

“The possibility bothers you that much?” he said.

“Maybe no more than how much seeing me dance with Lord Cerwyn bothered you,” she said harshly.

Sansa didn’t know what she was saying before she’d said it and almost said something to take it back but when she saw the way Jon’s face darkened, she realized this was the reaction she wanted from him.

“Are you saying it’s the same thing?” he asked.

“Which is what exactly? Love or camaraderie?”

“You’re being impossible, Sansa.”

“Either way, it probably isn’t the same, Jon.” Her words were spilling out of her. “Considering that I would never put him before you and you love your silver-haired queened more than—-”

“Than what?” he said, his anger returning. “More than what, Sansa, I want to hear you say it.” He touched her wrist and when she didn’t move away this time, he took both of her hands in his, her nails digging into his skin.

“I want to hear you say your cruelest insult to me!” he said, leaning into her face.

She jutted hers into his. “It isn’t an insult if it’s the truth!”

“You believing something so stubbornly doesn’t make it true!” he said, holding onto her tighter. “I would never betray you.” He looked at her with an earnestness so fierce it made her legs weak. “I would never — I would never put anyone else above you! I would never see you in danger ever again. I would never… I would never —”

Neither of them knew who moved forward first only that they’d come together in a breathless embrace that ignited a spark within both of them. Jon’s hands no longer held Sansa’s, instead they held either side of her face while Sansa’s hands gripped his wrists, her body bowed toward him.

It was a kiss as contradictory as everything before it; the softness of Jon’s lips, the feel of them on her own unwound Sansa as release surged through her — the taste of her tongue, the way her hands clenched his own filled Jon with an unparalleled relish but these emotions also triggered others, triggered questions they could feel rise within them, triggered more agitation, more … passion — it did nothing to satiate.

Finally, they parted and Sansa sank toward the desk as Jon walked swiftly over to a wall so he could sag his weight against something solid. Now that they were apart, they could breathe again and they each took in the air with a gluttonous enthusiasm, trying to calm their thundering hearts, dry their teary eyes, still their racing minds. They dared not look at each other because now that they were apart, they could feel the pull between them; within each of them was an urge to snap back together, an urge so intense it was like a humming on their skin.

And afraid of what would happen if they stayed in the same place, afraid at his own longing to find out, to go to her, Jon hastily left the room without looking back to see Sansa gripping the desk with one hand and clutching her chest with the other.

I was inspired to keep on going. Hope you guys like it! Once again, I’m not heavy into GoT, like I’m not too good with Houses and with customs etc. etc. so bear with me.

Sansa could hear it as she strode through the corridors. Giggling. Whispering. It was coming from an empty chamber. Choruses of “shh!” “shh!” and more guffawing. She was on her way to a council with Jon and the others but her curiosity got the best of her and she stopped outside of the room in question, its door half-closed, and saw a few servants huddled together.

           “I mean, it makes sense doesn’t it? Nothing makes a man lose his senses like a good roll in the hay.”

           The laughing stopped the minute Sansa made her presence known and the servants disassembled from a circle and formed a line, bowing their heads to her.

           “Lady Stark,” they intoned.

[[MORE]]

           She closed the door fully and walked closer to where they stood. “What is it that you are all talking about?”

           No one said anything. She sighed.

           “I know that you’re all gossiping in here, just tell me what it is.”

Two servants exchanged nervous glances. “Forgive us, Lady Stark—”

“You’re not in any trouble,” she said with a slight smile. “I’m just … curious. Indulge me.”

A woman started to speak. “Lady Stark, we … … we heard a rumour—”

“Yes,” said Sansa, nodding. “That much has been made clear.” She regarded them. “Out with it.”

There was another pause before the woman continued speaking. “One of the servants, I’m not sure who exactly, heard some of the boat crew talking,” she said. “And…”

Sansa stared at her. Her heart began to race as dread creeped up on her and started squeezing her chest: maybe she didn’t want to hear the answer. Maybe it was a rumour that would shatter something inside of her. It was the only explanation for the sense of impending doom that was disrupting her body.

“His Grace, Lord Snow, he and the Targaryen woman … they … they had relations on the boat…”

“That is the gossip anyway, my Lady,” said a man.

Nothing could have prepared Sansa for those words; they struck her like a slap and she felt winded with the impact. More than that she felt betrayed in a way she hadn’t expected. There was an intimacy to her sense of betrayal, an intimacy that shook her because it made her feel as if Jon had been unfaithful rather than traitorous, adulterous even and that only spawned a familiar confusion in Sansa, the one that had plagued her after every interaction she’d had with Jon since he came back.

It was as if her insides were being ripped apart with the whirlwind of conflicting emotions and all she could do to hold herself together was remove herself from them, block herself from the surprising pain and all of its implications, turn herself into steel, into that statuesque demeanour she found herself inhabiting more and more.

“Thank you, that will be all,” she said. Her jaw tight. “You can get back to your duties.”

“My Lady.”

 

Jon sat opposite Daenerys at a long wooden table covered with maps and documents. He was staring down at nothing in particular, stewing in a broody silence that infected the entire room. Daenerys had seen moments of this beforehand but nothing quite so long-lasting.

“It is unlike Sansa to be late,” he said.

Daenerys regarded him. “You’re worried about her?”

“I’m …” He gesticulated. “Regretful that we haven’t been getting along lately.”

“Because of me,” said Daenerys.

“No, because she doesn’t trust me. Because she’s stubborn. Because she doesn’t have faith in my loyalty to—” He cut himself off and shook his head.

Daenerys saw the heartbreak in Jon’s eyes as he said those words, heard the way his voice quickened with frustration and with a need, even then, to make his sister understand his choices — he was always with Sansa, he carried her with him, and all of their impassioned discussions.

“Well anyone with eyes could see how much you love …” she licked her lips. “The North,” she finished diplomatically. “Perhaps she just needed some time to gain perspective.”

“Well then she would’ve done it after the meeting not before,” said Jon gruffly.

The door opened and he started but when he saw Davos walk in the room, he sat back in his chair, crestfallen.

“Your Grace,” he said swiftly. He stopped in the middle of the room and spoke just as quickly.

“You need to talk to your crew. They’re undisciplined and they have big mouths.”

Daenerys stood up. “I beg your pardon?”

Jon raised his hands in a calming manner, looking from Daenerys to Davos and then spoke.

“What is it?”

“There seems to be a rumour going around,” said Davos.

Daenerys looked at him, her head cocked upward and Jon narrowed his eyes at Davos’ awkward expression.

“A rumour that you two had …”

Jon didn’t need Davos to finish the sentence. Everything inside of him shifted. He could hear Daenerys scoff at the accusations, at Davos discussing methods to suppress the gossip but their words were distant echoes in his ears. He suddenly felt sick with worry, with anxiety.

“Did Sansa hear?” he whispered.

They continued to talk.

He cleared his throat. “Did Sansa hear?” he said more loudly.

“Uh…” Davos shrugged. “I’m not sure if any of your siblings heard, Your Grace, right now it seems to be confined to the common folk, I —”

“I need to find her,” said Jon. He looked to Daenerys. “Excuse me.”

 

Jon walked into Sansa’s room without knocking, closing the door behind him. She was sitting at her desk, looking over documents. Although he was restless, he didn’t dare speak but she did nothing to acknowledge his presence in her chambers. He wanted to pace but he also wanted to stay still, he wanted to shout at her to look at him but he also wanted to give her the first word. He was unusually ambivalent and unusually frazzled and he couldn’t understand the guilt that was the source of his agitation.

Finally, she spoke.

“Do you love her?” she asked quietly, her eyes still on the document in front her.

“Sansa—-”

“Do. You. Love. Her.”

Jon sighed and hung his head then took a couple of steps closer to her desk. Finally she looked at him. Her eyes blazing with that wintry fire he so admired, that wintry fire that contradicted the coolness of her speech. She shrugged her shoulders.

“I don’t know if it would make this mean something or feel like it means something if you were in love with her.”

“Sansa, stop it.”

“Well surely,” she leaned back in her chair and shook her head, “if you are going to give away our autonomy, our freedom, it should be for love, should it not?”

“Sansa.”

She stood up and slammed her hands on the desk. “You tried to make me feel like a fool for questioning your motivations for this decision.”

“Well you were being a bit foolish,” Jon snapped back. “You’re being foolish right now!”

“Am I?” she yelled. Her pretence of aloofness cracking. “Because the last time someone from our family made a decision based on a woman, he ended up dead! My mother ended up dead! Northerners ended up dead! I told you you had to be smarter than Father, that you had to be smarter than Robb! And you’re making the same mistakes—”

Jon slammed his hands on the desk now too, his face inches away from Sansa’s. “I am not making the same mistakes!” he yelled. “I would never do anything to put the North at risk, to put Arya and Bran at risk, to put you at risk, Sansa! How many times do we have to have the same argument?”

“Until you convince me!” The shrillness of her own yelling surprised Sansa, it was a mark of how personal she was taking the entire situation and she tried to regain some emotional distance.

“Do you know how weak this makes us look? The King in the North now a puppet because he doesn’t think with his head!”

“Sansa, that’s enough!” He took a beat. “I would never—!”

“Oh, you’re too blinded that you don’t even see it!”

Swiftly, Sansa wrenched her eyes from Jon’s gaze and turned her back to him, rubbing her forehead with her right hand. She was feverish, her skin was hot to the touch.

“Too blinded to see what?” said Jon.

He waited for a response and when he didn’t get one, something in him compelled him to shout. “What am I too blinded to see?”

Sansa whirled around. “That you have chosen her!” she yelled. “Over — over—” Me, she screamed internally. You chose an outsider over me! And I hate it and I don’t know why I hate it this much!

Jon walked around the desk to her, he touched her shoulder but she couldn’t bear the thought of him holding her with the same hands he held her and she stepped out of his reach. While Jon itched to try again, he stayed where he was, giving her the space that she demanded, as he had and would continue to ensure that never again would she be touched unless she’d wanted to be.

She stared at him, breathing heavily and he shook his head, doing his best to calm the rage within him. He took a step toward her and stopped, maintaining a distance. “I—” he pressed his lips together. “I never knew you thought so little of me.”

She rolled her eyes. “That isn’t what I’m saying.”

“Isn’t it?” he countered. “If you so … passionately believe that I would put everything and everyone at risk for something as crude as sex or as selfish as love then I —”

“So you do love her,” she said severely, her eyes flashing.

He looked at her wearily. “Look, I loved a woman once,” he said. “A Wildling woman, her name was Ygritte and even my love for her couldn’t come before my duty to the Night’s Watch, what makes you think anything can come before my duty to —” You. “My people?”

“You love her,” she repeated.

Jon gritted his teeth, opening and closing his fists. “Why do you keep saying that?”

“Why don’t you deny it?” she retorted.

He looked at her, his mouth agape, as something — a new emotion — tickled his chest. Something that felt a bit like hope or a bit like delight.

“The possibility bothers you that much?” he said.

“Maybe no more than how much seeing me dance with Lord Cerwyn bothered you,” she said harshly.

Sansa didn’t know what she was saying before she’d said it and almost said something to take it back but when she saw the way Jon’s face darkened, she realized this was the reaction she wanted from him.

“Are you saying it’s the same thing?” he asked.

“Which is what exactly? Love or camaraderie?”

“You’re being impossible, Sansa.”

“Either way, it probably isn’t the same, Jon.” Her words were spilling out of her. “Considering that I would never put him before you and you love your silver-haired queened more than—-”

“Than what?” he said, his anger returning. “More than what, Sansa, I want to hear you say it.” He touched her wrist and when she didn’t move away this time, he took both of her hands in his, her nails digging into his skin.

“I want to hear you say your cruelest insult to me!” he said, leaning into her face.

She jutted hers into his. “It isn’t an insult if it’s the truth!”

“You believing something so stubbornly doesn’t make it true!” he said, holding onto her tighter. “I would never betray you.” He looked at her with an earnestness so fierce it made her legs weak. “I would never — I would never put anyone else above you! I would never see you in danger ever again. I would never… I would never —”

Neither of them knew who moved forward first only that they’d come together in a breathless embrace that ignited a spark within both of them. Jon’s hands no longer held Sansa’s, instead they held either side of her face while Sansa’s hands gripped his wrists, her body bowed toward him.

It was a kiss as contradictory as everything before it; the softness of Jon’s lips, the feel of them on her own unwound Sansa as release surged through her — the taste of her tongue, the way her hands clenched his own filled Jon with an unparalleled relish but these emotions also triggered others, triggered questions they could feel rise within them, triggered more agitation, more … passion — it did nothing to satiate.

Finally, they parted and Sansa sank toward the desk as Jon walked swiftly over to a wall so he could sag his weight against something solid. Now that they were apart, they could breathe again and they each took in the air with a gluttonous enthusiasm, trying to calm their thundering hearts, dry their teary eyes, still their racing minds. They dared not look at each other because now that they were apart, they could feel the pull between them; within each of them was an urge to snap back together, an urge so intense it was like a humming on their skin.

And afraid of what would happen if they stayed in the same place, afraid at his own longing to find out, to go to her, Jon hastily left the room without looking back to see Sansa gripping the desk with one hand and clutching her chest with the other.

“That is the gossip anyway, my Lady,” said a man.

Nothing could have prepared Sansa for those words; they struck her like a slap and she felt winded with the impact. More than that she felt betrayed in a way she hadn’t expected. There was an intimacy to her sense of betrayal, an intimacy that shook her because it made her feel as if Jon had been unfaithful rather than traitorous, adulterous even and that only spawned a familiar confusion in Sansa, the one that had plagued her after every interaction she’d had with Jon since he came back.

It was as if her insides were being ripped apart with the whirlwind of conflicting emotions and all she could do to hold herself together was remove herself from them, block herself from the surprising pain and all of its implications, turn herself into steel, into that statuesque demeanour she found herself inhabiting more and more.

“Thank you, that will be all,” she said. Her jaw tight. “You can get back to your duties.”

“My Lady.”

 

Jon sat opposite Daenerys at a long wooden table covered with maps and documents. He was staring down at nothing in particular, stewing in a broody silence that infected the entire room. Daenerys had seen moments of this beforehand but nothing quite so long-lasting.

“It is unlike Sansa to be late,” he said.

Daenerys regarded him. “You’re worried about her?”

“I’m …” He gesticulated. “Regretful that we haven’t been getting along lately.”

“Because of me,” said Daenerys.

“No, because she doesn’t trust me. Because she’s stubborn. Because she doesn’t have faith in my loyalty to—” He cut himself off and shook his head.

Daenerys saw the heartbreak in Jon’s eyes as he said those words, heard the way his voice quickened with frustration and with a need, even then, to make his sister understand his choices — he was always with Sansa, he carried her with him, and all of their impassioned discussions.

“Well anyone with eyes could see how much you love …” she licked her lips. “The North,” she finished diplomatically. “Perhaps she just needed some time to gain perspective.”

“Well then she would’ve done it after the meeting not before,” said Jon gruffly.

The door opened and he started but when he saw Davos walk in the room, he sat back in his chair, crestfallen.

“Your Grace,” he said swiftly. He stopped in the middle of the room and spoke just as quickly.

“You need to talk to your crew. They’re undisciplined and they have big mouths.”

Daenerys stood up. “I beg your pardon?”

Jon raised his hands in a calming manner, looking from Daenerys to Davos and then spoke.

“What is it?”

“There seems to be a rumour going around,” said Davos.

Daenerys looked at him, her head cocked upward and Jon narrowed his eyes at Davos’ awkward expression.

“A rumour that you two had …”

Jon didn’t need Davos to finish the sentence. Everything inside of him shifted. He could hear Daenerys scoff at the accusations, at Davos discussing methods to suppress the gossip but their words were distant echoes in his ears. He suddenly felt sick with worry, with anxiety.

“Did Sansa hear?” he whispered.

They continued to talk.

He cleared his throat. “Did Sansa hear?” he said more loudly.

“Uh…” Davos shrugged. “I’m not sure if any of your siblings heard, Your Grace, right now it seems to be confined to the common folk, I —”

“I need to find her,” said Jon. He looked to Daenerys. “Excuse me.”

 

Jon walked into Sansa’s room without knocking, closing the door behind him. She was sitting at her desk, looking over documents. Although he was restless, he didn’t dare speak but she did nothing to acknowledge his presence in her chambers. He wanted to pace but he also wanted to stay still, he wanted to shout at her to look at him but he also wanted to give her the first word. He was unusually ambivalent and unusually frazzled and he couldn’t understand the guilt that was the source of his agitation.

Finally, she spoke.

“Do you love her?” she asked quietly, her eyes still on the document in front her.

“Sansa—-”

“Do. You. Love. Her.”

Jon sighed and hung his head then took a couple of steps closer to her desk. Finally she looked at him. Her eyes blazing with that wintry fire he so admired, that wintry fire that contradicted the coolness of her speech. She shrugged her shoulders.

“I don’t know if it would make this mean something or feel like it means something if you were in love with her.”

“Sansa, stop it.”

“Well surely,” she leaned back in her chair and shook her head, “if you are going to give away our autonomy, our freedom, it should be for love, should it not?”

“Sansa.”

She stood up and slammed her hands on the desk. “You tried to make me feel like a fool for questioning your motivations for this decision.”

“Well you were being a bit foolish,” Jon snapped back. “You’re being foolish right now!”

“Am I?” she yelled. Her pretence of aloofness cracking. “Because the last time someone from our family made a decision based on a woman, he ended up dead! My mother ended up dead! Northerners ended up dead! I told you you had to be smarter than Father, that you had to be smarter than Robb! And you’re making the same mistakes—”

Jon slammed his hands on the desk now too, his face inches away from Sansa’s. “I am not making the same mistakes!” he yelled. “I would never do anything to put the North at risk, to put Arya and Bran at risk, to put you at risk, Sansa! How many times do we have to have the same argument?”

“Until you convince me!” The shrillness of her own yelling surprised Sansa, it was a mark of how personal she was taking the entire situation and she tried to regain some emotional distance.

“Do you know how weak this makes us look? The King in the North now a puppet because he doesn’t think with his head!”

“Sansa, that’s enough!” He took a beat. “I would never—!”

“Oh, you’re too blinded that you don’t even see it!”

Swiftly, Sansa wrenched her eyes from Jon’s gaze and turned her back to him, rubbing her forehead with her right hand. She was feverish, her skin was hot to the touch.

“Too blinded to see what?” said Jon.

He waited for a response and when he didn’t get one, something in him compelled him to shout. “What am I too blinded to see?”

Sansa whirled around. “That you have chosen her!” she yelled. “Over — over—” Me, she screamed internally. You chose an outsider over me! And I hate it and I don’t know why I hate it this much!

Jon walked around the desk to her, he touched her shoulder but she couldn’t bear the thought of him holding her with the same hands he held her and she stepped out of his reach. While Jon itched to try again, he stayed where he was, giving her the space that she demanded, as he had and would continue to ensure that never again would she be touched unless she’d wanted to be.

She stared at him, breathing heavily and he shook his head, doing his best to calm the rage within him. He took a step toward her and stopped, maintaining a distance. “I—” he pressed his lips together. “I never knew you thought so little of me.”

She rolled her eyes. “That isn’t what I’m saying.”

“Isn’t it?” he countered. “If you so … passionately believe that I would put everything and everyone at risk for something as crude as sex or as selfish as love then I —”

“So you do love her,” she said severely, her eyes flashing.

He looked at her wearily. “Look, I loved a woman once,” he said. “A Wildling woman, her name was Ygritte and even my love for her couldn’t come before my duty to the Night’s Watch, what makes you think anything can come before my duty to —” You. “My people?”

“You love her,” she repeated.

Jon gritted his teeth, opening and closing his fists. “Why do you keep saying that?”

“Why don’t you deny it?” she retorted.

He looked at her, his mouth agape, as something — a new emotion — tickled his chest. Something that felt a bit like hope or a bit like delight.

“The possibility bothers you that much?” he said.

“Maybe no more than how much seeing me dance with Lord Cerwyn bothered you,” she said harshly.

Sansa didn’t know what she was saying before she’d said it and almost said something to take it back but when she saw the way Jon’s face darkened, she realized this was the reaction she wanted from him.

“Are you saying it’s the same thing?” he asked.

“Which is what exactly? Love or camaraderie?”

“You’re being impossible, Sansa.”

“Either way, it probably isn’t the same, Jon.” Her words were spilling out of her. “Considering that I would never put him before you and you love your silver-haired queened more than—-”

“Than what?” he said, his anger returning. “More than what, Sansa, I want to hear you say it.” He touched her wrist and when she didn’t move away this time, he took both of her hands in his, her nails digging into his skin.

“I want to hear you say your cruelest insult to me!” he said, leaning into her face.

She jutted hers into his. “It isn’t an insult if it’s the truth!”

“You believing something so stubbornly doesn’t make it true!” he said, holding onto her tighter. “I would never betray you.” He looked at her with an earnestness so fierce it made her legs weak. “I would never — I would never put anyone else above you! I would never see you in danger ever again. I would never… I would never —”

Neither of them knew who moved forward first only that they’d come together in a breathless embrace that ignited a spark within both of them. Jon’s hands no longer held Sansa’s, instead they held either side of her face while Sansa’s hands gripped his wrists, her body bowed toward him.

It was a kiss as contradictory as everything before it; the softness of Jon’s lips, the feel of them on her own unwound Sansa as release surged through her — the taste of her tongue, the way her hands clenched his own filled Jon with an unparalleled relish but these emotions also triggered others, triggered questions they could feel rise within them, triggered more agitation, more … passion — it did nothing to satiate.

Finally, they parted and Sansa sank toward the desk as Jon walked swiftly over to a wall so he could sag his weight against something solid. Now that they were apart, they could breathe again and they each took in the air with a gluttonous enthusiasm, trying to calm their thundering hearts, dry their teary eyes, still their racing minds. They dared not look at each other because now that they were apart, they could feel the pull between them; within each of them was an urge to snap back together, an urge so intense it was like a humming on their skin.

And afraid of what would happen if they stayed in the same place, afraid at his own longing to find out, to go to her, Jon hastily left the room without looking back to see Sansa gripping the desk with one hand and clutching her chest with the other.

Sansa could hear it as she strode through the corridors. Giggling. Whispering. It was coming from an empty chamber. Choruses of “shh!” “shh!” and more guffawing. She was on her way to a council with Jon and the others but her curiosity got the best of her and she stopped outside of the room in question, its door half-closed, and saw a few servants huddled together.

           “I mean, it makes sense doesn’t it? Nothing makes a man lose his senses like a good roll in the hay.”

           The laughing stopped the minute Sansa made her presence known and the servants disassembled from a circle and formed a line, bowing their heads to her.

           “Lady Stark,” they intoned.

summary: How are you so sure jonsa is gonna happen? I would be happy if it is real but I don't really have much faith in it.
question: How are you so sure jonsa is gonna happen? I would be happy if it is real but I don't really have much faith in it.
answer:
I’m sure because I have a really really really strong conviction in my ship! This fandom is amazing and is filled with so many brilliant meta writers and smart individuals who have such a strong grasp on how I believe the story is supposed to play out! Also besides metas, Jon and Sansa have so many historical parallels and book hints that at this point it’s just way to hard to ignore. On top of that Jon and Sansa makes sense!! That’s the biggest

So yeah, I’ve never been in the wavering camp and at this point it’s not even a question if Jonsa is happening. To me it ABSOLUTELY is happening and now I just speculate on how it’s going to play out.

summary: Upon reflection of most people’s reaction to Sansa’s wedding night to Tyrion- she’s an ableist, ungrateful brat etc. etc.-...
question: Upon reflection of most people’s reaction to Sansa’s wedding night to Tyrion- she’s an ableist, ungrateful brat etc. etc.- wouldn’t really change to a positive had she smiled and welcomed his attentions. It would just change to “ OMG did you see that? She’s such a traitor, she’s such a wimp, she’s sleeping with her family’s enemy! I hope she dies!”
answer:
Hey anon,

I agree with you wholeheartedly. Unfortunately, she can’t win, can she? either she’s frightened of Tyrion, wants nothing to do with him at all, doesn’t want to marry him, isn’t attracted to him (and if we’re talking about the books he actually molests her) and therefore is ableist etc etc or she’s a traitor to her family and weak and “unstark” if she doesn’t fight him whilst he rapes her. She can’t win, and the hatred of the fandom towards her for this is both truly baffling as well as sickening. She’s a child, forcibly married to an enemy of her house. She has no power, no agency in this situation she did not ask for or deserve in the slightest. And yet the fandom hates her for it and the way she endures her situation. 

Instead of hating a child political prisoner, why not hate some of the truly despicable characters in the series, like Joffrey, for example? Instead of hating a frightened, traumatised child, hate Tyrion for his bitter resentment of his child-bride in the books. Rightly despise him for lusting after her and molesting her when he even admits to himself that it’s wrong and does it anyway. In the show, her refusal to consummate her marriage IS a form of defiance, subtle though it is. It shows she’s still fighting, still enduring. Sansa’s feelings about her forced marriage, in both the books and the show, are absolutely, entirely valid. And instead of hating her for them we should be applauding her bravery and resilience in the face of horror. And anyone who disagrees with that, well, I don’t care. All I can say is that anyone who hates Sansa for how she feels about her forced marriage - go and look up what ‘empathy’ means if you even know what a dictionary is.  

/rant over :)

summary: Do you think Sansa will ever see Theon again before the series end? Will he come to her aid to help fight the WW after he...
question: Do you think Sansa will ever see Theon again before the series end? Will he come to her aid to help fight the WW after he rescues his sister?
answer: Definitely. I doubt Theon will be uninvolved in the WW plot given that the show has proclaimed him a Stark and a Greyjoy. It would be a fitting end for his arc if he defends Winterfell and his siblings.

summary: Anyone who negatively judges Sansa for her disapproval towards Arya playing with peasants or Catelyn's fear towards Jon...
body:
Anyone who negatively judges Sansa for her disapproval towards Arya playing with peasants or Catelyn’s fear towards Jon (problematic views but completely realistic for their times) but excuses grown men being sexually attracted to and marrying children with the defense of “that’s just how it was back then, get over it!” when no, it was not, you historically challenged turnip are losing their rights. You don’t get the play the “realistic history” card when it suits you and disregard it when it doesn’t, especially when you can’t even play it correctly!

I don’t make the rules, but I wouldn’t be sorry even if I did.

summary: The needle trembled in her hand. Sansa needed to keep her mind off things, and sewing calmed her. Needlework was home. She’d...
body:
The needle trembled in her hand. Sansa needed to keep her mind off things, and sewing calmed her. Needlework was home. She’d abandoned her thimble long ago. Callouses had formed at the tips of her fingers. Many argued that a lady’s hand should be soft and delicate. No, that was impractical. Like all warriors, hands needed to be trained to heal and adapt. No longer was she the girl who had giggled with friends, ignorant to the world around her. No, she was a warrior of a different sort. A seamstress was a different sort of soldier. A fighter with threads, silks, and leftover scraps that some might find useless. Nothing ever went to waste for her. Frayed bits of fabric could be stored and saved. If anything, used as a stuffing for a deflating pillow or mattress. 

What others deemed as weakness, Sansa had made her strength, and one of the few things she still clung to from childhood. Happier times and memories.

A cloak represented the warmth and love of Mother. The dresses? Proof that she survived the battles, and won wars just like Robb. A new dress, a new victory.

The embroideries that glittered and sparkled? Familial pride and long forgotten smiles from better days.

Mother, Father, Robb, Rickon. They were gone from this world, but their spirits remained. Guided her.

Sansa took a deep breath, and steadied the needle in her hand before plunging it into the fabric.

Stitch by stitch, they lived again.

summary: ever since the fandom and some casual fans (and even folks who don’t watch the show or read the books) called out the over the...
body:
ever since the fandom and some casual fans (and even folks who don’t watch the show or read the books) called out the over the top hatred for sansa, some people have decided to use the feminist cards they awarded themselves to accuse sansa of everything from fascism to war crimes (i’m not exaggerating) in order to draw sympathy away from her. suddenly she’s the only classist character who benefits from all the trapping of feudalism (shame on sansa fans for wishing she’d be queen. don’t they know that she’ll be using unpaid labour???), she’s also racist even thought it was jeyne who was scared of the summer islander prince, she started the war of the five kings and is responsible for everyone who died because of it, she’s the only one who is ableist towards tyrion especially on their wedding. (even though he was like 5 seconds from sexually assaulting her), etc.

they’ve been accusing sansa of social crimes and actual crimes for years. then they want to complain about us for being too overprotective.

summary: can’t get past jon fathering a bastard. maybe to others it’s ironic or something, but there is just no way... where would this...
question: can’t get past jon fathering a bastard. maybe to others it’s ironic or something, but there is just no way... where would this “pure” baby even fit in the future? the dragons went mad because they knew they were dragons and felt entitled enough to keep their arrogance going. therefore jon was spared, being raised by wolves. what do you think that means for the wolf dragon blooded children from then on between sansa and jon? there shouldn’t be any coin flipping for them, right?
answer:
Hey, nonnie!

I agree. I have a pretty visceral reaction to the idea of Jon fathering a bastard for all the reasons I’ve detailed in other posts. I think on a purely narrative level, I get why people would think it could happen because it seems that this story sometimes insists in forcing their characters to live through their worst nightmares but at this point Jon has been hit with so many nightmares that I think there’s really no point in twisting the knife even further (pun intended). 

The reason why I don’t believe it will happen is because of D*ny’s arc as “mother of dragons” which would be at complete odds with her giving birth to a human baby. Also the exploration of what would happen to a half-Targ baby in a world where Targs are reviled has already been done with Jon and we will get the painful pay-off of that in season 8. 

So there are only a few reasons why this b0atie would come to pass: 

1. Gratuitous narrative punishment for Jon and putting Sansa in the same spot her mother occupied and forcing her to atone for Cat’s mistakes. As I’ve said there is no reason why Jon should be punished again. 

As for Sansa, first and foremost, she is not responsible for what Cat did or failed to do and the fact that she looks like her physically shouldn’t be an excuse. In addition she will already atone for Cat’s failures with Jon by protecting, loving and making him a Stark. So having to do that with a bastard Targ baby is overkill. 

Then there’s the simple matter that Sansa, just like Jon, has been through enough bitter experiences and while a baby is a baby and I’m sure she’d be a wonderful mother to him/her, there’s no reason to put her through another painful situation when we’re still waiting for the pay-off of having her finally be truly happy after 7 seasons of being hurt over and over again. 

2. History repeating itself - “Everything you will see is something you’ve seen before”. Cool … However, by that logic, we should have an entire story that simply just reverts back to the beginning and nothing of note truly changes. That would feel like an utter waste of time. 

3. Targ restoration - what is there to say on this, really? Jon/D*ny/b0atie rule Westeros in a frenzy of dragon fire, exceptionalism and “bend the knee or die” speeches. Which means that the entire focus on the Targaryens being fucked up, doing far more harm than good and essentially going mad that is not only present in the actually story but in each and every additional material GRRM has put out, was just done for funs and giggles. Nothing to concern yourself with. Aryan exceptionalism is actually the way forward for Westeros. If that’s the story I’ve been watching and reading, I’m going to consider that all my time analyzing it and taking it seriously would have been for nothing. 

what do you think that means for the wolf dragon blooded children from then on between sansa and jon? there shouldn’t be any coin flipping for them, right?

“When a Targaryen is born, the Gods flip a coin” is an in-story saying. It’s like us saying: “ Don’t bite the hand that feeds you“ or countless other such expressions. 

It came about because after a while people noticed that their inbred rulers weren’t quite right in the head and that by and large almost all of them ended up doing things that you could only equate to madness. I don’t think anyone did a statistical study to see if one in 2 Targs went mad or what the balance was exactly. 

If we look at each individual case, their symptoms differ from individual to individual. The one thing they have in common is their obsession with fire and dragons. There’s a case to be made that this hankers back to whatever blood magic ritual the Valyrians used to bond dragons to humans but for being half-Targ, Jon isn’t really plagued with dragon dreams or fantasies. Perhaps he will be once he comes into contact with them but I think his bond with Ghost will protect him from the negative effects of that particular symptom. 

The narrative import of  “When a Targaryen is born, the Gods flip a coin” is limited to Jon and D*ny specifically because they’re the only 2 Targs left so the duality of a coin flip is a way of foreshadowing Jon and D*ny in conflict and acting as foils for one another. 

As for Jon and Sansa’s potential children, it’s difficult to say much of anything. There’s of course the nature vs. nurture aspect that needs to be brought up. D*ny didn’t just become who she is in a vaccum. Her whole life experience lead her down this path and having no positive role models during her formative years informs her actions to this day. She lacks a moral compass in a way and despite her good intentions, she never manages to find it. 

Jon and Sansa’s children will, on the other hand, be brought up in a loving home by two moral and kind people so that’s bound to have an effect on how they view the world and what kind of people they end up being. On the other hand, every human being has flaws and perhaps some of their children will display what could be interpreted as Targ characteristics. The important thing is what they choose to focus on. 

Thanks for the ask!

The narrative import of  “When a Targaryen is born, the Gods flip a coin” is limited to Jon and D*ny specifically because they’re the only 2 Targs left so the duality of a coin flip is a way of foreshadowing Jon and D*ny in conflict and acting as foils for one another. 

As for Jon and Sansa’s potential children, it’s difficult to say much of anything. There’s of course the nature vs. nurture aspect that needs to be brought up. D*ny didn’t just become who she is in a vaccum. Her whole life experience lead her down this path and having no positive role models during her formative years informs her actions to this day. She lacks a moral compass in a way and despite her good intentions, she never manages to find it. 

Jon and Sansa’s children will, on the other hand, be brought up in a loving home by two moral and kind people so that’s bound to have an effect on how they view the world and what kind of people they end up being. On the other hand, every human being has flaws and perhaps some of their children will display what could be interpreted as Targ characteristics. The important thing is what they choose to focus on. 

Thanks for the ask!
trail.content:
Hey, nonnie!

I agree. I have a pretty visceral reaction to the idea of Jon fathering a bastard for all the reasons I’ve detailed in other posts. I think on a purely narrative level, I get why people would think it could happen because it seems that this story sometimes insists in forcing their characters to live through their worst nightmares but at this point Jon has been hit with so many nightmares that I think there’s really no point in twisting the knife even further (pun intended). 

The reason why I don’t believe it will happen is because of D*ny’s arc as “mother of dragons” which would be at complete odds with her giving birth to a human baby. Also the exploration of what would happen to a half-Targ baby in a world where Targs are reviled has already been done with Jon and we will get the painful pay-off of that in season 8. 

So there are only a few reasons why this b0atie would come to pass: 

1. Gratuitous narrative punishment for Jon and putting Sansa in the same spot her mother occupied and forcing her to atone for Cat’s mistakes. As I’ve said there is no reason why Jon should be punished again. 

As for Sansa, first and foremost, she is not responsible for what Cat did or failed to do and the fact that she looks like her physically shouldn’t be an excuse. In addition she will already atone for Cat’s failures with Jon by protecting, loving and making him a Stark. So having to do that with a bastard Targ baby is overkill. 

Then there’s the simple matter that Sansa, just like Jon, has been through enough bitter experiences and while a baby is a baby and I’m sure she’d be a wonderful mother to him/her, there’s no reason to put her through another painful situation when we’re still waiting for the pay-off of having her finally be truly happy after 7 seasons of being hurt over and over again. 

2. History repeating itself - “Everything you will see is something you’ve seen before”. Cool … However, by that logic, we should have an entire story that simply just reverts back to the beginning and nothing of note truly changes. That would feel like an utter waste of time. 

3. Targ restoration - what is there to say on this, really? Jon/D*ny/b0atie rule Westeros in a frenzy of dragon fire, exceptionalism and “bend the knee or die” speeches. Which means that the entire focus on the Targaryens being fucked up, doing far more harm than good and essentially going mad that is not only present in the actually story but in each and every additional material GRRM has put out, was just done for funs and giggles. Nothing to concern yourself with. Aryan exceptionalism is actually the way forward for Westeros. If that’s the story I’ve been watching and reading, I’m going to consider that all my time analyzing it and taking it seriously would have been for nothing. 

what do you think that means for the wolf dragon blooded children from then on between sansa and jon? there shouldn’t be any coin flipping for them, right?

“When a Targaryen is born, the Gods flip a coin” is an in-story saying. It’s like us saying: “ Don’t bite the hand that feeds you“ or countless other such expressions. 

It came about because after a while people noticed that their inbred rulers weren’t quite right in the head and that by and large almost all of them ended up doing things that you could only equate to madness. I don’t think anyone did a statistical study to see if one in 2 Targs went mad or what the balance was exactly. 

If we look at each individual case, their symptoms differ from individual to individual. The one thing they have in common is their obsession with fire and dragons. There’s a case to be made that this hankers back to whatever blood magic ritual the Valyrians used to bond dragons to humans but for being half-Targ, Jon isn’t really plagued with dragon dreams or fantasies. Perhaps he will be once he comes into contact with them but I think his bond with Ghost will protect him from the negative effects of that particular symptom. 

The narrative import of  “When a Targaryen is born, the Gods flip a coin” is limited to Jon and D*ny specifically because they’re the only 2 Targs left so the duality of a coin flip is a way of foreshadowing Jon and D*ny in conflict and acting as foils for one another. 

As for Jon and Sansa’s potential children, it’s difficult to say much of anything. There’s of course the nature vs. nurture aspect that needs to be brought up. D*ny didn’t just become who she is in a vaccum. Her whole life experience lead her down this path and having no positive role models during her formative years informs her actions to this day. She lacks a moral compass in a way and despite her good intentions, she never manages to find it. 

Jon and Sansa’s children will, on the other hand, be brought up in a loving home by two moral and kind people so that’s bound to have an effect on how they view the world and what kind of people they end up being. On the other hand, every human being has flaws and perhaps some of their children will display what could be interpreted as Targ characteristics. The important thing is what they choose to focus on. 

Thanks for the ask!
